Introduction

Achondroplasia is a skeletal dysplasia caused by a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene that results in decreased endochondral ossification.  Most mutations are de novo, but achondroplasia can also be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.  Patients have a short stature with disproportionately short arms and legs as well as craniofacial abnormalities (eg, macrocephaly, frontal bossing, midface hypoplasia).

Genetics and risk factors



Achondroplasia is the most common type of skeletal dysplasia.  It is an autosomal dominant condition that can occur as a de novo mutation or can be inherited:



  • De novo mutation (80% of cases):  Advanced paternal age increases the risk for a sporadic mutation due to increased DNA replication errors during spermatogenesis.
  • Inherited mutation (20% of cases):  Inheritance of a single mutant allele causes the disorder; therefore, if one parent is affected, 50% of children will inherit the condition (
    figure 1
    ).  Inheritance of 2 mutant alleles (ie, both parents are affected and pass on the mutation) is lethal.

Pathogenesis



Achondroplasia is a condition that results in decreased endochondral ossification.  This is the process by which bone replaces cartilage during skeletal growth.  It normally occurs throughout the body, including in long bones and the bones that comprise the base of the skull.  In the growth plate (physis), chondrocytes progress through distinct zones:  the resting zone, the proliferative zone (where they divide), and the hypertrophic zone (where they enlarge and align in columns) (

figure 2
).  These cells become surrounded by a mineralizing matrix in the zone of provisional calcification.



Achondroplasia is caused by a point mutation in the FGFR3 gene, which codes for a protein that normally acts as a negative regulator of cartilage proliferation.  The receptor becomes constitutively active (gain-of-function mutation), primarily affecting the proliferation and hypertrophy of chondrocytes in the growth plate during endochondral ossification.  Patients develop characteristic shortened long bones (eg, humerus, femur, phalanges) and craniofacial abnormalities (eg, midface hypoplasia).



Most of the flat bones in the skull undergo intramembranous ossification rather than endochondral ossification and are relatively unaffected in patients with achondroplasia.

Clinical presentation



Achondroplasia is a congenital condition; many features are apparent at birth and become more evident with skeletal maturity (

figure 3
).



Skeletal abnormalities



  • Disproportionate short stature (short arms/legs with average-size torso).
  • Rhizomelia (shortened proximal extremities).
  • Brachydactyly (shortened digits).
  • Trident configuration (increased space between 3rd and 4th digits).
  • Genu varum (bowed legs).
  • Thoracolumbar kyphoscoliosis with lumbar hyperlordosis (
    figure 4
    ).


Craniofacial features



  • Macrocephaly.
  • Midface hypoplasia (flattened nasal bridge).
  • Frontal bossing (broad forehead).


Patients may have hypotonia and delayed motor development early in life.  Cognition is normal.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Achondroplasia is suspected when prenatal ultrasonography or postnatal examination demonstrates characteristic short limbs and craniofacial features.



Diagnosis is confirmed by molecular genetic testing showing the FGFR3 mutation.

Differential diagnosis



Achondroplasia must be differentiated from other congenital conditions that cause skeletal or craniofacial abnormalities.



  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (
    figure 5
    ):  A congenital defect in the type I collagen structure results in increased bone fragility.  Patients may have short stature and bowing deformities of long bones.  Rhizomelia and midface hypoplasia are not seen.  In addition, other features such as recurrent fractures with minimal trauma, blue sclera, and weak/discolored teeth are present.
  • Rickets (
    figure 6
    ):  Abnormal mineralization during bone growth can result in short stature, gross motor delays, frontal bossing, and genu varum.  Patients with rickets do not have rhizomelia or brachydactyly.
  • Inborn errors of metabolism:  Metabolic disorders, such as mucopolysaccharidoses, can present as skeletal dysplasia with shortened long bones, kyphoscoliosis, and flattened midface.  Patients typically have additional neurologic (eg, intellectual disability) and gastrointestinal (eg, hepatomegaly) features.
  • Teratogen exposure:  Teratogens (eg, alcohol) can interfere with the normal growth of tissues in a developing fetus.  Fetal alcohol syndrome presents with characteristic facial abnormalities such as midface hypoplasia (
    figure 7
    ).  Disproportionate short stature is not seen.  In addition, these patients are likely to have learning disabilities and microcephaly.

Prognosis and complications



Both men and women with achondroplasia typically reach an average adult height of about 4 feet (121.9 cm).  Most patients have a normal lifespan; however, there is an increased rate for childhood mortality due to cervicomedullary compression secondary to foramen magnum stenosis.



Common non-life-threatening complications of achondroplasia are often related to craniofacial abnormalities and include recurrent otitis media, hearing loss, and obstructive sleep apnea.  In addition, abnormal vertebral development can lead to spinal stenosis, which presents with lower extremity weakness/paresthesia and bladder dysfunction in adulthood.

Management



A multidisciplinary team (eg, orthopedist, physical/occupational therapist) should address potential disease complications (eg, spinal stenosis) and help patients adapt to challenges related to having shortened limbs (ie, promoting accessibility and independence).  Genetic counseling should also be provided to patients with achondroplasia.

Summary



Achondroplasia (
